1.title:  Zits : Chillax
1.author: Jerry Scott and Jim Borgman.
notes: Summary (from OCLC): Anticipating an epic first rock concert that he will attend unsupervised, Jeremy plans to dedicate his expected night of debauchery to his friend Tim, who is donating bone marrow to his cancer patient mother on the same night.
Illustrated prose format.

5.title:  Zits. Jeremy & Dad : a Zits Tribute-ish to Fathers and Sons

6.title:  Zits. Random Zits
6.author: by Jerry Scott and Jim Borgman.
notes: Poster (1 sheet : col. ill. ; 60 x 53 cm. folded to 21 x 27 cm.) laid in at p. 3 of cover.

Summary (from OCLC): "Random Zits not-so-randomly combines the previous collections Road Trip! and Teenage Tales into one mega-volume. It includes popular story lines that include Jeremy and Hector fixing up their old van and take it for a clandestine joy ride, and Jeremy learning the value of tact on his girlfriend's bad hair days, selling random household items on eBay, surviving sudden radical growth spurts, and being coaxed into a fishing trip with his father, who seizes the opportunity to have "the talk." Zits captures the nature of teenage boys with uncanny precision. In one series of strips, Jeremy's mom is alarmed when she finds a fist-size hole in the wall of his room. Pressed to explain it, he balks. When he finally describes what happened, it turns out that the hole wasn't made in a moment of teen hormonal rage. It was made in a moment of teen hormonal idiocy, when he used his mom's meat tenderizing mallet to swat a bug. Anyone who has spent much time around an adolescent boy will recognize this seemingly inexplicable behavior: intelligence and impulsiveness locked in constant battle. This is the natural state of the teen male, and it's portrayed exquisitely in Zits."

110.title:  Zits Sketchbook ; 8 Teenage Tales
110.author: by Jerry Scott and Jim Borgman.
notes: (Zits Sketchbook ; 8)

Summary (from OCLC): "Fifteen-year-old Jeremy Duncan is the heart and soul of puberty. A typical teen, Jeremy is shy, self-absorbed, and bored. He loves hanging out and playing the guitar, and is constantly befuddled at his parents' uncoolness. He lives in the shadow of his older brother's perfect 4.0 grade-point-average, star athlete, flawless complexion image. Jeremy's girlfriend, Sara, loves that she can get him to do anything for her. His best friends are Hector and Pierce, whom he's known for-almost-ever. His parents? Uncool baby boomers. Unless you're a parent. Then they are two suburban professionals trying to do the best they can with a teenager going through that "awkward" phase. The enormously popular comic strip Zits depicts teenage and parental angst like no other. Teenage Tales is a cornucopia of recent Zits for die-hard fans everywhere."

115.title:  A Zits Treasury. Alternative Zits: a Zits Treasury
115.author: Jerry Scott and Jim Borgman.
notes: "Includes cartoons from Are we out of the driveway yet? and Rude, crude, and tattooed.

116.title:  A Zits Treasury. Big Honkin' Zits : a Zits Treasury
116.author: by Jerry Scott and Jim Borgman.
notes: Family strip.

117.title:  A Zits Treasury. Crack of Noon : a Zits Treasury
117.author: by Jerry Scott and Jim Borgman.

118.title:  A Zits Treasury. Humongous Zits : a Zits Treasury
118.author: by Jerry Scott and Jim Borgman.
notes: "Includes cartoons from Zits and Growth Spurt."

119.author: Jerry Scott and Jim Borgman.

120.title:  Zits Unzipped. Unzipped
120.author: by Jerry Scott and Jim Borgman.
notes: (Zits Sketchbook ; no. 5)
Other title: Zits Unzipped.
Family strip.

121.title:  Zits Unzipped. Zits Supersized : a Zits Treasury
121.author: Jerry Scott and Jim Borgman.
notes: "Contains the director's cut of Good Night, Dude."
"Includes cartoons from Zits Unzipped and Busted!"

122.title:  Zitz, A. B. "The Conspirators"
122.author: De Beck
122.series: Barney Google and Spark Plug, Nov. 4, 1930
122.appears_in: p. 161 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Schnopps and Zitz outfit Opal Showers for her role, though her mother and fiancé don't like it.

123.title:  Zitz, A. B. "Help Yourself to My Cigars and Make Yourself at Home"
123.author: De Beck
123.series: Barney Google and Spark Plug, Oct. 2, 1930
123.appears_in: p. 156 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Barney has hired a lawyer, A.B. Zitz, to recover his $8 from the senator.

124.title:  Zitz, A. B. "I Wonder Which Floor the Senator's On?"
124.author: De Beck
124.series: Barney Google and Spark Plug, Oct. 7, 1930
124.appears_in: p. 157 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Barney climbs a light pole to try and see the meeting between Zitz and the senator.

125.title:  Zitz, A. B. "The Lady Awaits, Come at Once"
125.author: De Beck
125.series: Barney Google and Spark Plug, Oct. 20, 1930
125.appears_in: p. 159 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Shows and describes the current cast of characters: Tom-Tom, Senator Schnopps, Barney, Zitz, Madame La Mousse, and Lena her pet, a big cat shown here with stripes like a tiger.

126.title:  Zitz, A. B. "The Music Will Quiet Your Nerves"
126.author: De Beck
126.series: Barney Google and Spark Plug, Oct. 28, 1930
126.appears_in: p. 160 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Senator Schnopps is distraught because Barney is visiting La Mousse. Zitz turns on the radio, and a man is singing a song called "Bubble Eyes."

127.title:  Zitz, A. B. "My Client has Fainted!"
127.author: De Beck
127.series: Barney Google and Spark Plug, Oct. 3, 1930
127.appears_in: p. 156 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Zitz produces a check for $25,000 written by Senator Schnopps to Barney Google.

128.title:  Zitz, A. B. "Opal Showers, the Private Secretary"
128.author: De Beck
128.series: Barney Google and Spark Plug, Oct. 30, 1930
128.appears_in: p. 161 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Schnopps and Zitz are going to try to make La Mousse jealous by introducing an 'other woman.'

129.title:  Zitz, A. B. "She Is a Dangerous Vampire"
129.author: De Beck
129.series: Barney Google and Spark Plug, Oct. 21, 1930
129.appears_in: p. 159 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Barney is going to call on Madame La Mousse, because "that Arab of hers" brought an invitation. Zitz warns him about tigers and leopards, so Barney goes to buy some raw meat.

130.title:  Zitz, A. B. "That Scrap of Paper Found on Senator Schnopps"
130.author: De Beck
130.series: Barney Google and Spark Plug, Oct. 10, 1930
130.appears_in: p. 157 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Lawyer Zitz sees the love letters, and wants to check the handwriting on something else.

131.title:  Zitz, A. B. "Their Wedding Should Be the Social Event of the Season"
131.author: De Beck
131.series: Barney Google and Spark Plug, Nov. 15, 1930
131.appears_in: p. 163 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Barney wants to take Senator Schnopps's offer and leave for China, Zitz thinks his plan is working out fine and the senator will marry Madame La Mousse, Opal thinks Barney is a real gentleman, and Tom-Tom is encouraging Barney (with his spear) to go back to La Mousse.

132.title:  Zitz, A. B. "These Priceless Jewels Were My Gift To Her"
132.author: De Beck
132.series: Barney Google and Spark Plug, Oct. 17, 1930
132.appears_in: p. 158 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Senator Schnopps explains to Zitz that he is in love with Madame La Mousse, a princess and the world's most beautiful woman, but she sent back the jewels and is infatuated with Google.

133.title: Zits
notes:   Newspaper comic strip by Jerry Scott and Jim Borgman. See also the collected volumes titled Zits Sketchbook and A Zits Treasury.
